data.title: What time is Doctor Who: The Power of the Doctor on tonight? When it starts on BBC One and cast in full
data.meta_description: The centenary special celebrates 100 years of the BBC
data.text:
The centenary episode of Doctor Who: The Power of the Doctor – is set to air tonight on BBC One.

The special show marks the 100th anniversary of the BBC, as well as the final episode for current Doctor – Jodie Whittaker.

Whittaker joined the series five years ago as the 13th, and first female, Doctor.

The new trailer shows Whittaker being welcomed “to the end of your existence”, as she takes on her final battle.

What time is Doctor Who on tonight?

Doctor Who will air on BBC One at 7.30pm tonight (Sunday 23 October) following the Strictly Come Dancing results.

The special has an hour and a half running time and will finish at 9.30pm.

It will also be available to catch up on iPlayer.

Full cast list of Doctor Who

The cast will include a few familiar faces, including returnees such as Sacha Dhawan, Sophie Aldred and Janet Fielding.

Jodie Whittaker as Doctor Who

Mandip Gill as Yaz

Sacha Dhawan as The Master

Johns Bishop as Dan

Sophie Aldred as Ace

Janet Fielding as Tegan

Sophie Aldred played the Seventh Doctor’s companion, Ace, during the late 80s.

Between 1981 and 1984, Janet Fielding played the part of Tegan Jovanka, a companion of the Fourth Doctor for his four-episode story Logopolis (played by Tom Baker), and later of the Fifth Doctor, Peter Davison, in 18 of his stories.

She also appeared in the regeneration sequence for his final, nineteenth story.

Sacha Dhawan appeared in four episodes of the twelfth series of Doctor Who as the incarnation of the renegade Time Lord, known as the Master, an archenemy of the Doctor.

Who is the new Doctor?

Whittacker will be replaced by 29-year-old Sex Education actor Ncuti Gatwa. Scottish actor Mr Gatwa, who was born in Rwanda, will be the series’ first black Doctor.

He appeared in episodes of Bob Servant and Stonemouth before being cast as Eric Effiong in the Netflix series Sex Education, which was released in 2019.

The critically acclaimed teen drama has now run for three series and Gatwa has been widely praised by critics, with i describing him as Sex Education‘s “breakout star,” who “steals the show”.

His performance earned him three consecutive Bafta TV Award nominations for best male comedy performance between 2020 and 2022.

Gatwa has also won a Bafta Scotland Award for best actor in television and a Royal Television Society Award for best comedy performance.

On stage, he has appeared as Demetrius in A Midsummer Night’s Dream at Shakespeare’s Globe theatre, while he is part of a star-studded cast in the upcoming romantic comedy film Barbie, directed by Greta Gerwig.

Speaking of the role in an official BBC statement, Gatwa said: “There aren’t quite the words to describe how I’m feeling. A mix of deeply honoured, beyond excited and of course a little bit scared.

“This role and show means so much to so many around the world, including myself, and each one of my incredibly talented predecessors has handled that unique responsibility and privilege with the utmost care. I will endeavour my utmost to do the same.”

He is expected to make his first appearance as the 14th Doctor in 2023.

Speaking of the end of her time on the show, Whittaker said: “This family grows and it will be bigger than us and it will go on, and Ncuti will be extraordinary and he will bring an audience that we haven’t reached and his performance will be so magical.

“I’m certainly not going to give that phenomenal actor any advice, he doesn’t need it from me. Just, it’s yours to own and you’ve earned it.”

Who are the previous Doctors?

In order of appearance, here are all the actors who have played the iconic Time Lord over the decades.

William Hartnell 1963 – 1966

Patrick Troughton 1966 – 1969

John Pertwee 1970 – 1974

Tom Baker 1974 – 1981

Peter Davidson 1981 – 1984

Colin Baker 1984 – 1986

Sylvester McCoy 1987 – 1989

Paul McGann 1996

Christopher Eccleston 2005

David Tennant 2005 – 2010

Matt Smith 2010 – 2013

Peter Capaldi 2013 – 2017

Jodie Whittaker 2017 – present

The centenary special Doctor Who: The Power of the Doctor will air on Sunday 23 October on BBC One at 7.30pm
